snippet.textDisplay:
Helicopters go down a lot more than reported. It only makes the "NEWS" if someone dies. And, of course it only makes National News if someone famous dies.

Black boxes should be mandatory so we can improve helicopter's performance and reduce fatalities. That's just common sense.
snippet.textOriginal:
Helicopters go down a lot more than reported. It only makes the "NEWS" if someone dies. And, of course it only makes National News if someone famous dies.

Black boxes should be mandatory so we can improve helicopter's performance and reduce fatalities. That's just common sense.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s not the NTSB, they made recommendations that the FAA decided did not to be implemented, according to the spokesperson that gave the press conference on Tuesday.  The pressure it seems needs to be placed on the FAA.
snippet.textOriginal: It’s not the NTSB, they made recommendations that the FAA decided did not to be implemented, according to the spokesperson that gave the press conference on Tuesday.  The pressure it seems needs to be placed on the FAA.

snippet.textDisplay: The takeaway seems to be not to fly through heavy fog, to have the FAA require black boxes and flight data recorders on helicopters, and to require them to have NTS terrain systems. It's easy looking from the outside in. The pilot was very experienced, so it's difficult to understand why he flew through fog. The problem is that, without those three things, it will be very difficult for anyone to know. All the NTSB will be able to do is guess. They know what they're doing, but it would still be undeniably easier to prevent situations like this if they have data.
snippet.textOriginal: The takeaway seems to be not to fly through heavy fog, to have the FAA require black boxes and flight data recorders on helicopters, and to require them to have NTS terrain systems. It's easy looking from the outside in. The pilot was very experienced, so it's difficult to understand why he flew through fog. The problem is that, without those three things, it will be very difficult for anyone to know. All the NTSB will be able to do is guess. They know what they're doing, but it would still be undeniably easier to prevent situations like this if they have data.

snippet.textDisplay:
🙌🙏💯"Better to know"..So apt Stephen. Aviation authorities, and the like can surely make it happen in this advanced tech age (mind you there was the man/men on the moon in 69, and we have peope living in space). My humble bewildered mind can not fathom why we wait to the nightmare is a reality before we act to protect ourselves. We do not have to wait! Let's dream a better moment and make it happen - mandatory blackbox for all. Thanks Baptise for reminding how life is too short, somehow in the sadness we find light and rise to count our blessings 🙌.
Thanks Stephen for sharing your humility, heart, and pain again..I lost my father and two brothers over a space of 25 years, I can only conceptualise what it is like to experience loss like you and other's in a single moment, it lifted my heart that through pain we can rise and share love, kindness, and make our world brighter and better🙏. Thank you, keep being you. 💯🙌.

My humble bewildered mind can not fathom why we wait to the nightmare is a reality before we act to protect ourselves. We do not have to wait! Let's dream a better moment and make it happen - mandatory blackbox for all. Thanks  Baptise for reminding how life is too short, somehow in the sadness we find light and rise to count our blessings 🙌.
Thanks Stephen for sharing your humility, heart, and pain again..I lost my father and two brothers over a space of 25 years, I can only conceptualise what it is like to experience loss like you and other's in a single moment, it lifted my heart that through pain we can rise and share love, kindness, and make our world brighter and better🙏.  Thank you, keep being you. 💯🙌.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a retired Military member, who lost my greatest mentor - Command Sergeant Major Cornell Gilmore, who was one of six soldiers killed when the Black Hawk helicopter they were flying in was struck by enemy fire and crashed near Tikrit on November 7, 2003...and as an ex-employee for FAA emergency ops...I completely appreciate what Stephen was saying.
Also, I know of the fragility of this helicopter - as I was also in a Black Hawk in a very foggy, icy cold January day, in Kosovo ...which before a returning take-off, I had this extreme eerily feeling that CSM Gilmore, was telling me not to allow lift-off...I'm glad I listened and grounded that travel.
snippet.textOriginal:
As a retired Military member,  who lost my greatest mentor - Command Sergeant Major Cornell Gilmore,  who was one of six soldiers killed when the Black Hawk helicopter they were flying in was struck by enemy fire and crashed near Tikrit on November 7, 2003...and as an ex-employee for FAA emergency ops...I completely appreciate what Stephen was saying.
Also, I know of the fragility of this helicopter - as I was also in a Black Hawk in a very foggy, icy cold January day, in Kosovo ...which before a returning take-off, I had this extreme eerily feeling that CSM Gilmore, was telling me not to allow lift-off...I'm glad I listened and grounded that travel.

snippet.textDisplay: I believe, from the recent press conference, that the NTSB suggests changes within their completed reports. This can take 12-18 months after the accident for their completed reports, and not simply the preliminary report. One of the reports provided is a safety report. Unfortunately it is up to a corporation/company (forget whom they said it deviates to) after that to look at the safety report provided, and suggestions provided by the NTSB to increase safety measures within the air craft, and choose to implement them as a means for prevention. The issue seems to lie in the fact that it's left up to being a choice, and not being a mandatory change to prevent further accidents from occurring. At least this is what I gathered from the press conference yesterday.
snippet.textOriginal: I believe, from the recent press conference, that the NTSB suggests changes within their completed reports. This can take 12-18 months after the accident for their completed reports, and not simply the preliminary report. One of the reports provided is a safety report. Unfortunately it is up to a corporation/company (forget whom they said it deviates to) after that to look at the safety report provided, and suggestions provided by the NTSB to increase safety measures within the air craft, and choose to implement them as a means for prevention. The issue seems to lie in the fact that it's left up to being a choice, and not being a mandatory change to prevent further accidents from occurring. At least this is what I gathered from the press conference yesterday.

snippet.textDisplay: Re: Nothing is done to improve the pilots.  Around 2007-2008 I was in a flight school to become a commercial helicopter pilot (it was intended to be a career change, but several factors, the most important of which was the recession, prevented me from doing that). Every time there was a helicopter crash, we would all (at least where I was training) eat up all the reports and carefully analyze the investigation to figure out what we could do to not let that happen to us. Of course, without recorders there isn't always a lot of useful information, but we'd try all the same.  I don't know if that habit continues up into the ranks of the professional pilot, but it was certainly prevalent in flight training.
snippet.textOriginal: Re: Nothing is done to improve the pilots.  Around 2007-2008 I was in a flight school to become a commercial helicopter pilot (it was intended to be a career change, but several factors, the most important of which was the recession, prevented me from doing that). Every time there was a helicopter crash, we would all (at least where I was training) eat up all the reports and carefully analyze the investigation to figure out what we could do to not let that happen to us. Of course, without recorders there isn't always a lot of useful information, but we'd try all the same.  I don't know if that habit continues up into the ranks of the professional pilot, but it was certainly prevalent in flight training.

snippet.textDisplay: If you remember plane crashes were constant in the 80's and 90's. When Captain Sully was praised for saving everyone's life on his plane he made the point it wasn't just him. It was everyone involved that day and involved in the last 30 years who worked to improve the airline industry by updating rules and creating industry standards of training and improving aircraft design. Now you rarely hear about plane crashes and this is the point Stephen is making. In order to improve anything you need information on what went wrong. You need to know what not to do. This tradegy was preventable and the NTSB needs to make more changes including adding black boxes to helicopters. That's an absolute minimum to begin to learn from this and prevent this from happening again. This helicopter also didn't have a terrain awareness and warning system in place. The NTSB asked the FAA to make it mandatory for passenger helicopters to have it and they didn't. If this aircraft would have had it then maybe the pilot could have cleared the hills. There's so much that could have been done and still can be.
snippet.textOriginal: If you remember plane crashes were constant in the 80's and 90's. When Captain Sully was praised for saving everyone's life on his plane he made the point it wasn't just him. It was everyone involved that day and involved in the last 30 years who worked to improve the airline industry by updating rules and creating industry standards of training and improving aircraft design. Now you rarely hear about plane crashes and this is the point Stephen is making. In order to improve anything you need information on what went wrong. You need to know what not to do. This tradegy was preventable and the NTSB needs to make more changes including adding black boxes to helicopters. That's an absolute minimum to begin to learn from this and prevent this from happening again. This helicopter also didn't have a terrain awareness and warning system in place. The NTSB asked the FAA to make it mandatory for passenger helicopters to have it and they didn't. If this aircraft would have had it then maybe the pilot could have cleared the hills. There's so much that could have been done and still can be.

snippet.textDisplay: Every aircraft flying in America should be equipped with TAWS (terrain awareness and warning system) to prevent these sorts of accidents (controlled flight into terrain) from happening. It's already law for large aircraft, they need to extend it to all. With those instruments/warning system, they would likely still be alive.
snippet.textOriginal: Every aircraft flying in America should be equipped with TAWS (terrain awareness and warning system) to prevent these sorts of accidents (controlled flight into terrain) from happening. It's already law for large aircraft, they need to extend it to all. With those instruments/warning system, they would likely still be alive.

snippet.textDisplay: The NTSB  has made several recommendations to help prevent more helicopter crashes after several crashes in the past, but the FAA failed to implement them. They reiterated those same recommendations yesterday (Tuesday, Jan 28), and also mentioned how the FAA failed to implement them,  and I think they made an new recommendation based on this tragic accident. Hopefully the FAA will act
snippet.textOriginal: The NTSB  has made several recommendations to help prevent more helicopter crashes after several crashes in the past, but the FAA failed to implement them. snippet.textDisplay:
Things to do regarding death and life:
1- disregard your beliefs about god's name and image.
2- just search for god by saying everyday from your heart ( god if you're really there, guide me to you)
3- keep living your life but make finding god a big priority
....
Follow these steps and follow your heart, success in your life is not what you were found for,
Your soul needs to be fed, just like your body and brain, it needs sustenance, and only god will ever help u out of your depression.

snippet.textDisplay: If they have black boxes on airplanes, they should find a way to do it for helicopters as well.  When it comes to having to bury a child, I remember what President Kennedy once said.  In 1963 when he had to bury his newborn son, President Kennedy said, "It is against the laws of human nature for a parent to bury their child."  Regardless of what you think about President Kennedy, and their are both good things and things not so good (As is the case with any human being), he was 100 percent right on this one.  I know how heartbroken my mom was when she had to bury my youngest sister.  My wife told my mom that their will always be a hole in her heart.  The hole will be covered with scar tissue, but the hole will always be there.  She told my mom that you never get over the death of a child regardless of how old they are.  That you try to cope with it as best as you can.
snippet.textOriginal: If they have black boxes on airplanes, they should find a way to do it for helicopters as well.  When it comes to having to bury a child, I remember what President Kennedy once said.  In 1963 when he had to bury his newborn son, President Kennedy said, "It is against the laws of human nature for a parent to bury their child."  Regardless of what you think about President Kennedy, and their are both good things and things not so good (As is the case with any human being), he was 100 percent right on this one.  I know how heartbroken my mom was when she had to bury my youngest sister.  My wife told my mom that their will always be a hole in her heart.  The hole will be covered with scar tissue, but the hole will always be there.  She told my mom that you never get over the death of a child regardless of how old they are.  That you try to cope with it as best as you can.
